comments.body: Should hours (and other fields) be in some range? See the table from the SQL:2016 If not, please, explain.

Well, it's true that the range of fields such as hour breaks SQL:2016. And other interval related functions such as `make_interval` and `make_ym_interval` have same problem. Further more, MySQL and PostgreSQL have same behavior, following is the example of PG:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2949045/122197365-b0cef180-ceca-11eb-81af-4427dc6e55a2.png)

So, I think we should keep the consistency with other functions first, and launch a discussion for further decision.
By the way, could you give me the link of the SQL:2016 image by adding a new comment?

comments.body:
Now I understand why we need a new version of `fromYearMonthString`, as we need to allow `INTERVAL ... YEAR TO MONTH`. Let's make it clear in the PR description.

Let's add a new method `castStringToYMInterval`, and define a new regex for it.
Doneï¼Œ how about current?
nice catch!
Shall we fail if the day field is not 0? Or at least give a warning?

We don't fail when we convert:

1. `java.sql.Date` has time component with millisecond precision but we ignore it when we convert to days at https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/56e664c7179eadeb5134b4418f3aaa6a9d742ef6/sql/catalyst/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/sql/catalyst/util/DateTimeUtils.scala#L93
2. `java.sql.Timestamp` which has nanoseconds precision: https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/56e664c7179eadeb5134b4418f3aaa6a9d742ef6/sql/catalyst/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/sql/catalyst/util/DateTimeUtils.scala#L166
3. `java.time.Instant` which contains nanoseconds, and we don't fail when we convert it to microseconds: https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/56e664c7179eadeb5134b4418f3aaa6a9d742ef6/sql/catalyst/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/sql/catalyst/util/DateTimeUtils.scala#L383

To be consistent with current implementation for other types, I do believe we should not fail.

> Or at least give a warning?

This will just fill in the logs by useless records, and this is again inconsistent with current implementation.

comments.body: shall we check the precision as well?
We can check it but `precision` value is not important for this code...or I am wrong?
So, `Decimal` guarantees that `precision` >= `scale` (@Ngone51 correct?). That's enough for the code.

Technically, I think we should say `DecimalType`  guarantees `precision` >= `scale`. But since any `Decimal` is directly or indirectly bounded with a `DecimalType`. Therefore, `Decimal` also guarantees `precision` >= `scale`.
I just want to be consistent with https://github.com/apache/spark/pull/28886/files#diff-b83497f7bc11578a0b63a814a2a30f48R2003
I added assert there to guarantee that Int will not overflow. What would you like to assert here?
for sanity check? The `precision` must be `<= 8` here, right?
Not anymore, please, take a look at https://github.com/apache/spark/pull/28873 and https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SPARK-32021

comments.body: since `1.` is allowed, I don't think `fractionScale < initialFractionScale` is a valid check any more.
we need this, the cases are (`1.0`, `0.1`, `.1`,  `1.`) + (`.`), this condition is equal to `!(pointPrefixed && fractionScale == initialFractionScale)`
rm `fractionScale < initialFractionScale` forbiding `.1` case
ah i see!

comments.body: probably add a comment saying that the `toString` implementation is the multi-units format.
The comment is useless from my point of view. It describes what is obvious from the code but does not say why.
agree. @yaooqinn can you refine the comments to explain why? We should mention that it's to support `.1 second`
OK
This may be an old idea, but I thought the java Enum class was the preferred way to define enums in scala, even?
I haven't found this requirement in the Scala coding guide. Where does it come from (do you have some links for related discussions)?

At least, there are 46 places where Scala's `Numeration` is used:
```shell
$ find . -name "*.scala" -print0|xargs -0 grep -n 'extends Enumeration'|wc -l
      46
```

It's stuff like: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/scala-internals/8RWkccSRBxQ%5B1-25%5D

But indeed we use scala.Enumeration widely, and I think the issues crop up when interoperating with Java, or in more obscure cases. I think it's fine here.
This is intended to be internal only?
yes
we can move `CalendarInterval.toString` to here with name `toMultiUnitsString`. `CalendarInterval.toString` should be as simple as `CalendarInterval(months = ..., days = ..., microseconds = ...)`
We can do it in a followup
Yea sounds great
shouldn't we add `-`?
yes it is likely `-1.toString` here
wow, a single `0` is also SQL standard?

```sql
postgres=# set IntervalStyle=sql_standard;
SET
postgres=# select interval '0';
 interval
----------
 0
(1 row)

postgres=# set IntervalStyle=postgres;
SET
postgres=# select interval '0';
 interval
----------
 00:00:00
(1 row)
```
